node.text: Take a sneak peek into the noisy cavern of the largest particle detector in the world @atlasexperiment with Theo Alexopoulos and @chit_chet_ and look at the experiment’s newest addition - the New Small Wheels 🔵

node.title: Live from the ATLAS Cavern and Small Wheels Lab

node.text:
With the Proton Synchrotron and its Booster accelerating protons to high energies again, the physics season can start at the ISOLDE radioactive ion beam facility. 💥💻 

During several #upgradingLHC activities, two new target stations have been installed at ISOLDE and protons are back for studying physics.

#PhotoOfTheWeek by @leauickque and @chit_chet_
🎵: Your Gain

node.title: Physics season at CERN’s ISOLDE facility

node.text:
CERN lays first stone of Science Gateway 🪨 

Scheduled to open in 2023, CERN is increasing its capacity to welcome visitors of all ages, from near and far and extending its educational portfolio with a view to increasingly inspiring future generations towards science and research. 

What are you most excited to see inside #CERNScienceGateway? 😀

🎥 by Titouan Robin Chapuis, @chit_chet_

node.text:
Happy 50th birthday hadron colliders! 🙌

#ThrowbackThursday #TBT 

50 years ago, CERN scientists collided particles in the first hadron collider ever built. On 27 January 1971, CERN’s Intersecting Storage Rings (ISR) produced the world’s first proton–proton collisions.
Physicists had planned this machine in the 1960s, based on the idea that smashing two particle beams head on would give much higher energies than colliding a single beam of particles with a fixed target. 

This first hadron collider helped change the views of members of the physics community, who doubted the usefulness of hadron colliders. By the time it shut down in 1984, it had produced many important results, including indications that protons contain smaller constituents, ultimately identified as quarks and gluons.

node.text:
Since the Standard Model leaves many questions unanswered, physicists have proposed theories that go beyond it, some of which explain the nature of dark matter. Among such theories are those suggesting the existence of axions or axion-like particles. These theories need to be tested, and many experiments have been set up around the world to look for these particles, including at CERN. 

One antimatter experiment at CERN, BASE, has now, for the first time, turned the tools developed to detect single antiprotons, the #antimatter equivalent of a proton, to the search for #darkmatter! 😍

node.text:
#Doyouknow why matter dominates over antimatter in the universe? 😲

This situation makes a detailed study of antimatter of immense significance not just for physics but also for cosmology. 🌌

25 years ago, CERN announced producing the first atoms of antimatter. This handful of antihydrogen atoms were created on the Low Energy Antiproton Ring (LEAR), a machine used to accumulate and store antiprotons. The international team from @forschungszentrum_juelich, @uni_fau, @universeinthelab, and @unigenova led by Walter Oelert succeeded for the first time in linking an antiproton and a positron, but for a very short time. ⏱🔍

#ThrowbackThursday #TBT 

🎞 The experiment had only 48 hours of beam time during the very last months of the LEAR machine and its success opened the path to a new antimatter machine, the Antiproton Decelerator (AD), that hosts several experiments studying #antimatter today. 💯

node.title: First Atoms of Antimatter at CERN

node.text:
#ThrowbackThursday to 1966, playing Cluedo at a sub-nuclear level 🎲⠀
 ⠀
#DidYouKnow that particle tracks used to be analysed on scanning tables like this one? The combination of bubble chambers and scanning tables demanded a lot of ingenuity but allowed surprisingly precise results. ⠀
 ⠀
Like deducing who is guilty in the detective game of Cluedo, particle-hunters had to deduce the number, type, moment and energy of the particles involved. They had to reconstruct the spatial geometry of the tracks left by the charged particles in the bubble chamber, and then apply the laws of conservation of energy and momentum to the initial and final particles.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on September 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '+Z NEAR'.

node.text:
Particle physics with pepperoni 🍕⠀
 ⠀
When new tech hits your eye like a big pizza pie, that's an upgrade! This #PhotoOfTheWeek was taken in the @cmsexperiment, where the team introduced to us Calabrese, Capricciosa, Diavola, and Margherita, the four slices of the new upgraded BRIL detector. ⠀
 ⠀
Among others, BRIL will measure the real-time rate of collisions at the LHC and the luminosity. Each subsystem of the detector represents a new generation design. BRIL is now ready for the #Run3 of the #LHC. 🤩⠀
⠀
📸: Andrés Delannoy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on September 10, 2021.

node.text:
These are the magnet doors of the @alice_experiment, impressive giants of 16 metres in height and weighing 350 tonnes... each! They protect  the detector, built to study matter in conditions similar to those moments after the Big Bang, and ensure the reliability of the data being collected.

#FunFact: these doors are so massive that opening or closing them takes about three days! 💪

📸 by @arthur.images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Elementary my dear Sheldon 🔎 ⠀
 ⠀
#ThrowbackThursday to Physics @nobelprize_org winner Sheldon Glashow, paying a visit to CERN in December 1979. ⠀
 ⠀
Sheldon Glashow won his prestigious prize alongside Abdus Salam and Steven Weinberg for their work in explaining the interactions of elementary particles. Their theory, unifying the electromagnetic and weak forces, was unanimously applauded. 👏⠀
 ⠀
When Sheldon Glashow visited CERN in December 1979, he had just received his prize in Stockholm. In the photo, you can see him giving a seminar “Making do without the top quark".

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on September 08, 2021. May be an image of bird and outdoors.

node.text:
A new mascot for CERN? ☀️

#PhotoOfTheWeek
 
As colleagues paused for lunch last week, a flock of storks also paused on the roof of CERN’s main building, before migrating southwards. 
 
Usually, storks migrate twice a year. The first trip takes the birds from their wintering grounds to their nesting grounds. The second trip is the one we witnessed last week. It goes in the opposite direction and takes the storks to their winter quarters. 
 
Which animal do you think could represent CERN as its official mascot? 

📸 by @piotr_traczyk_

node.text:
This may look like a spider’s web, but it’s for something much smaller than insects: what you see here is the installation of a new beam pipe in the LHCb facility. Through the study of beauty quarks, the @lhcbexperiment investigates the slight differences between matter and antimatter. 

To hunt these quarks, we use a 5600-tonne LHCb detector that is 21 metres long, 10 metres high and 13 metres wide. But as you can see in this photo, this giant is a marvel of complexity that has to be manipulated very carefully! 

Do you know the other name of the beauty quark? 

📸: @julienordan, @samhertzog

node.text:
#ThrowbackThursday: monitoring the parameters bit by bit 👩‍💻
 
When the Proton Synchrotron division renewed its booster controls in 1981, they installed 25 microprocessors as auxiliary crate controllers. These microprocessors had to monitor close to a thousand parameters whose values changed from cycle to cycle. 
 
The same auxiliary crate controllers were also developed at the heart of a stand-alone system that could be used on a mobile console to access the control systems locally. 
 
Much appreciated by the engineers and scientists, these microprocessors proved to be more reliable than the minicomputers that were used before. 🤩
 
Do you know in which year the booster received its first beam?

node.text:
ELENA is back in action ⚙️💥 #PhotoOfTheWeek
 
The Extra Low Energy Antiproton ring (ELENA) is part of CERN‘s antimatter factory and slows down antiprotons from CERN’s Antiproton Decelerator. This allows experiments to increase the number of antiprotons that they can capture.
 
After successful installation and commissioning of new transfer lines at the ELENA ring, the facility has now started delivering antiprotons at an energy of 100 keV to the physics experiments. Last week, the GBAR and ALPHA experiments have already taken beams and other experiments will follow soon.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on August 27, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
The heart of the detector 💚

Take a look at the installation of the beam pipe inside the detector of the @cmsexperiment. 

Right here, inside this beam pipe, the LHC beams collide at the interaction point. 

One of the main #upgradingLHC activities at CMS is the complete replacement of the CMS beam pipe to make it compatible with the geometry of the future CMS pixel detector.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on August 26, 2021. May be an image of standing and indoor.

node.text:
Garden of machines 🔧⠀
⠀
This #ThrowbackThursday takes us back to 1971 with the “ADAM and EVA system”. ⠀
⠀
The picture shows part of a scanning and measuring system used to analyze photographs taken in the Mirabelle hydrogen bubble chamber. On the right are film transport systems and projectors. On the left are control electronics. The table where views were projected in front of the operator is situated on the floor below...

node.text:
A”door”able Alice 🚪

The massive doors of the @alice_experiment are finally closed. This delicate operation took place at the end of July, and the magnets are now well protected behind these giants weighing 350 tonnes each. 
 
Closing of the doors symbolically marked the end of the maintenance and upgrading work on this experiment, as it now prepares for  #PhysicsSeason at the LHC next year. 
 
#PhotoOfTheWeek by @max.brice and @ana.ger21
